entries.content: Price is rarely the actual reason why people don't buy, even in competitive markets with many suppliers.
Prospects often use price as a tactic because they know sales people are conditioned to compete on it.
Don't compete on price. Know your value and be willing to say no to deals where price is the only factor.
"If price is going to be the only factor in which you make this decision, then we're out. We will never be cheapest."
entries.notes: Used to disqualify price-only prospects without attacking competitors.

entries.content: When asked for a discount, ask what you will get in exchange. Don't just give value away.
entries.notes: Asserts value even during negotiation, not just competing on lowest price.

entries.content: Understand your product's proven value and frame the interaction as the prospect needing to convince you why you should supply them.
entries.notes: Flips the dynamic, asserting value and uniqueness.

entries.content: Send pathologically cheap customers who only care about price to your biggest competitor.
entries.notes: Frames competitor as a place for undesirable customers, not attacking their offering.

entries.content: Ask prospects tendering for business: 'Other than price, what's going to be the key determining factor?'
entries.notes: Redirects focus away from price in competitive bids.

focus_area: Competitive Objections: Unique value framing without attacking others
